How a Little-Known French Region Safeguarded the Louvre’s Treasures During World War II
More than 3,000 artworks from national museums were stowed in chateaus in the Lot—about 350 miles south of Paris
There’s little fanfare at the entrance to Château de Montal, outside the village of Saint-Jean-Lespinasse in southwest France. In fact, as I arrive one Saturday afternoon in October, more cars are parked in a lot for the modern golf course that has sprung up near it than at the 16th-century castle obscured behind a curtain of oak trees.
Built for Jeanne de Balsac, Lady of Montal, between 1519 and 1534, Château de Montal is one of the rare early French castles to be commissioned by a woman. The daughter of Robert de Balsac, a knight and chamberlain to King Charles VIII, Jeanne was left to raise five children alone when her husband, Amaury de Montal, died in 1510.
The chateau’s early Renaissance style marked a transition from the medieval fortresses that dot a landscape so keenly fought over by the English and French during the Hundred Years’ War. Chiseled out of stone, the ornate busts of de Balsac’s family members hang beneath Sleeping Beauty-style turrets. The architecture also tells the story of grief. “Her eldest son, and heritor, Robert, died on the battlefield on a military campaign in Italy in 1523. She talks of her pain as a mother in the decoration,” says Sylvie Dusséaux, the deputy administrator of Château de Montal. The phrase plus d’espoir, or “no more hope,” is engraved into one of the stones.
The castle passed to her descendants upon her death in 1559 and was eventually abandoned in the late 1800s, when many of its architectural features were stripped and sold at auction. In the early 20th century, Maurice Fenaille, a French patron of the arts, purchased the chateau. “He invested colossal resources into the restoration, including setting out to buy back the pieces that had been sold at auction,” says Dusséaux. He managed to recoup 85 percent of the facade’s original sculptures. He commissioned the workshop of his friend, the artist Auguste Rodin, to create copies from plaster of those he couldn’t. Fenaille donated the chateau to the French state in 1913, while securing the right to continue living there for himself and his children. After decades of welcoming public visits only over the summer months, it opened to the public full-time in 2006.
Despite its fairy-tale silhouette and fascinating history, I’m not surprised to find myself among only a few people onsite as I walk through the rooms and garden at my own pace on a self-guided visit. Although Château de Montal is in France’s Dordogne Valley—named for the river that serpentines through it and famous as the land of 1,001 castles and for the prehistoric cave art at Lascaux—it’s in an area less frequented by tourists: the Lot.
More than 350 miles south of Paris, the Lot is one of France’s uncharted corners, despite exporting the inky red grape that grows from its soil, Malbec, to the world. Named for another river that flows through it, the Lot is also one of the country’s smaller departments: At a little over 2,000 square miles, it’s almost half the size of its better-known neighbor, the Dordogne department.
For more than two years at the end of World War II, from March 1943 until June 1945, however, the low-key setting of the Lot—and Château de Montal in particular—was exactly what was needed to answer a question Louvre curators had found themselves asking since before the war started: How do you solve a problem like the Mona Lisa?
Keeping the Mona Lisa safe
October 2025’s theft of €88 million ($102 million) worth of crown jewels from the Louvre shone a spotlight on how priceless the museum’s collection is not only in monetary value, but also in its role in French culture.
That’s why, as early as 1933, detailed plans were already underway to safeguard the collection should another war break out in Europe. “Multiple high-level authorities were involved, including the ministre de l’interieur [minister of the interior] and the ministre de l’education nationale [minister of national education], whose purview included the French national museums and thus the Louvre,” explains Gerri Chanel, author of Saving Mona Lisa, a comprehensive account of how the Louvre and its treasures were saved from the Nazis.
Everything owned by the Louvre, as well as other national museums, was protected under the Hague Conventions, written in 1899 and 1907. While that meant the Germans couldn’t freely help themselves to French public works of art, these laws of war couldn’t shield the art from the threat of destruction or looting.
In total, 5,667 crates from the national museums were evacuated from Paris starting September 1, 1939, the day Germany invaded Poland. At the Louvre, only the most fragile or bulky works of art were left in place. “The curators made detailed lists indicating the priority by which works should be evacuated,” says Chanel. A simple coding system was settled upon: A yellow dot was placed on most works, a green dot on works of major importance and a red dot for the most significant. Overseeing it all was the director of the national museums, Jacques Jaujard. “His heroism in protecting the Louvre’s artwork and antiques was extraordinary,” says Chanel.
In its purpose-built velvet-lined case inside a crate marked with little more than the letters MNLP0 (for Musées Nationaux Louvre Peintures No. 0) and three red dots—the only artwork to have been codified of utmost importance—“La Joconde,” as the French refer to Leonardo da Vinci’s most famous work, crisscrossed the country in the attempt to distance it from conflict, finding long-term safety in the Musée Ingres Bourdelle in the southwestern town of Montauban in October 1940. This was its fourth “safe house” after leaving Paris just over a year earlier.
By 1942, however, France in its entirety was occupied by the Germans (and Italians, in the southeast), and Montauban, with its strategically important location on the railroad just north of Toulouse, was no longer the haven it had once been.
Did you know? The Louvre is upgrading its security
“The aim was to stay as far away as possible from combat zones and from places that represented a military threat, particularly railway lines and sites linked to targets the army might want to bomb,” explains Ophélie Jouan, a Paris-based art historian.
Neighboring Lot, with its medieval castles, many isolated in forests, became the refuge that curators so desperately needed. The Mona Lisa, along with 1,300 other artworks, was sent to Château de Montal. Some 3,000 artistic treasures, including the Seated Scribe, the pride of the Louvre’s Egyptology collection, were concealed in seven other chateaus in the region’s thick woodlands, which also camouflaged France’s growing Resistance movement.
“These were places that were accessible by road but nevertheless away from main arteries,” Jouan says.
Louvre-sur-Lot
Today, Château de Montal is decorated with period furnishings acquired by Fenaille, such as tapestries, long banquet tables and four-poster beds. Sweeping stone staircases lead to a grand hall and bedrooms with vaulted ceilings and splendid stone fireplaces that overlook ornamental gardens. Explanatory signs are discreet, but tell the early history of the property, with much emphasis on Fenaille’s role in reviving it.
In the attic, a permanent exhibition chronicles the extraordinary two years of the “Louvre-sur-Lot,” as the era between 1943 and 1945 is colloquially referred to in the region. Through archival photographs and documents, as well as a short video, visitors learn that the ground-floor rooms were once jammed with 100 crates of art, including works by Antoine Watteau, Tintoretto and Édouard Manet. So necessary was every inch of space that some crates were stored behind heavy tapestries that still hang on the walls.
The Mona Lisa was set apart, its crate placed closest to the exit so it could be easily evacuated if necessary. It was constantly under watch—a bed set up next to it meant that even when guards were asleep, La Joconde was still within reach.
Like other “depots,” or art safe houses, during the war, Montal had a Louvre curator overseeing operations: Réné Huyghe. Across Montal and its four nearby satellite depots, he managed a team of 37 people and around–the-clock surveillance. Huyghe and his crew feared bombings and on-the-ground raids, not to mention normal wear on the artworks.
“Preservation in castles, abbeys and old stone buildings that were cold and damp was obviously not ideal,” says Jouan. The effect of humidity or moisture on the works was a constant worry—as was fire, accidental or otherwise. Curators constantly monitored the crates for signs of damage and organized routine fire drills. Thankfully, such catastrophes were never realized. In Montal, the Mona Lisa had found a place to see out the war.
Château de la Treyne and the “Seated Scribe”
Among the other chateaus in the Lot to shelter cultural treasures evacuated from Paris were Château de Béduer, which concealed much of the French film archives and now is the site of a popular women-only summer camp, Camp Château, and Château de la Treyne, which sits on a scenic bend of the Dordogne River outside the village of Lacave. Unlike Château de Montal, which belonged to the state, both properties were privately owned—Béduer by Jeanne Loviton, a lawyer and writer better known by her pen name, Jean Voilier, and la Treyne by the Fontana family from Spain.
Lucie Mazauric, who worked in the archives at the Louvre, spent April 1943 to November 1945 at la Treyne, alongside her husband, Louvre curator and author André Chamson, and their teenage daughter, Frédérique. They watched over 80 crates, mostly from the Egyptian Antiquities Department. The most precious artwork under their watch was the famous Seated Scribe, which dates from 2,500 B.C.E. (making it more than 4,500 years old). Discovered in Saqqara in 1850, the funerary relic of a cross-legged man writing on a roll of papyrus is made of limestone and reflects literate officials’ high rank in ancient Egyptian society.
In her memoir, Ma Vie de Châteaux, Mazauric describes la Treyne as “not very beautiful.” But in the decades since the war, the chateau has been carefully restored and is now a high-end hotel. As we pull into the driveway after the 45-minute drive from Montal, I feel like I’ve arrived on a medieval-film set. My 8-year-old daughter proclaims our top-floor room, which feels like a Rapunzel tower with views across the entire estate, the best hotel room she’s ever stayed in. She proceeds to disappear into the cubby purpose-built for kids and draw for most of the afternoon.
“People love hearing the story that this small statue [the Seated Scribe] was once in our home in la Treyne,” owner Stéphanie Gombert tells me. The property was purchased by the family of her husband, Philippe, in the 1980s and opened as a guest house before the couple took over ownership and transformed it into a five-star Relais & Châteaux property with a Michelin-starred restaurant that’s been helmed by the same chef, Stéphane Andrieux, for nearly 30 years.
No tangible evidence of the chateau’s Louvre-sur-Lot history remains for hotel guests to experience today, although Gombert has named a second-floor guest room “Scribe.” Hanging in its bathroom is a gouache painting the couple had made of the Seated Scribe.
Gombert learned that the presence of such works in the area was never a secret to locals. “People here knew, and they were proud,” she says. “The castle, in a way, belonged to them. Of course, it was private, but it was their place, too. It had to be defended at all costs.”
Hiding Rothschild art
While speculation on what works of national importance might be hidden nearby was likely popular at local farmers markets and village cafés, what wasn’t known was that la Treyne was also hiding some of the most valuable privately owned art in the world.
If the state’s collection was protected under the Hague Conventions, fair game in Nazi minds were the personal collections of wealthy Jewish families, such as the Rothschilds, a prominent European Jewish banking family. Amassed over generations, and reflecting a deep commitment to cultural patronage, their art collection included Old Master paintings, Renaissance sculptures, medieval manuscripts and decorative furniture. The Nazis looted more than 5,000 objects from various Rothschild collections during the war. That figure might have been higher, had it not been for Mazauric and Chamson, who, upon hearing that about 29 crates of Rothschild art were hiding in a prison deep in France’s Lozère region, undertook a journey to rescue them.
“They forged documents, making it look as if the Rothschild family’s collection was part of the national collection, and that’s how they managed to conceal them,” explains Benôit Kwietniak, a Lozère archivist who has documented this little-known chapter of history. The couple’s goal was simple: to include these works in all official inventories from la Treyne shared with the Kunstschutz, the Nazi department charged with protecting art during the war.
That’s how they safeguarded a veritable treasure chest of canvases, furniture and objects of art. “There was a Picasso, a Degas, three Rembrandts, three Renoirs, two Fragonards and two Watteaus among them,” says Kwietniak.
What’s more, not a single work was lost. “Everything was returned to the family at the end of the war,” he says. In a poetic footnote, the Louvre bought one of the pieces, the 18th-century Tabatière du Duc de Choiseul, or Choiseul snuffbox, in 2023 for €3.9 million ($4.6 million).
Heading home
After the war ended, the national works were similarly eventually repatriated to their original museums from their temporary homes in the Lot.
“It took time, for various reasons,” says Jouan. The France that emerged from the war was very different from the country it was before conflict broke out. “There were very limited resources, and the population was completely exhausted,” she adds.
The end of the war did not suddenly mean that money, fuel or vehicles were available. Rationing was still in place, and the winter of 1946 was extremely cold. “Sometimes it was preferable to keep the artworks where they were until the means existed to bring them back safely,” says Jouan—especially considering that no coal was available to warm the galleries at the Louvre, which wouldn’t truly reopen until 1947.
Before the collection returned home, the Louvre temporarily exhibited 13 canvases—among them Tintoretto’s self-portrait, Watteau’s La Finette and Jean Clouet’s portrait of François 1er—in Cahors, the biggest town in the Lot, to thank the local population for keeping such tokens of national heritage safe.
Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of this story is that despite the constant threat swirling around them, every single one of the 3,000-plus artworks that were safeguarded in the Lot returned to Paris, an achievement highly unlikely had it not been for the bravery of the Louvre’s curators who acted as sentinels for the duration of the war.
“We don’t really realize the level of risk that was taken at the time by the curators in order to protect the works of art,” says Jouan. Some, including Chamson, also became active members of the Resistance. “They went beyond their official duties as museum curators. They committed themselves body and soul.”

articles.content:
Masked Thieves Steal Statue of British Boxer Teddy Baldock From a London Park, Leaving Only His Boots Behind
Baldock, a former bantamweight world champion, was the only British boxer to win a world title in the 1920s. The statue had been in Langdon Park since 2014
Police are searching for the thieves who stole a bronze statue of Teddy Baldock, a celebrated British boxer, from a park in east London.
Footage captured by CCTV on the night of February 1 shows four people entering Langdon Park wearing dark clothes and face coverings. They jostled the statue free from its stone pedestal and stashed it in a three-wheel cargo bike before fleeing the scene. No tools appear to have been used in the heist, and only the fighter’s bronze boxing boots, affixed to the plinth, were left behind.
The statue’s metal is worth roughly $137,000, though its sentimental value is impossible to measure.
“I’m a mixture of upset and angry,” Martin Sax, Baldock’s 56-year-old grandson who helped raise money for the statue’s 2014 construction, tells the London Times’ Anna Dowell. “It’s an amazing piece of art and to think that people have stolen it, and all that’s going to happen is it’ll get melted down and they’ll get scrap value for an iconic statue in the center of London of a British sporting hero—it’s very sad, really.”
Known as the “Pride of Poplar,” Baldock was born in 1907 in London’s Poplar neighborhood. He became a professional boxer at the age of 14 and quickly won over the public with his “speed, skill and exciting fighting style,” writes BBC News.
After a successful early stint in rings around the United Kingdom—in which his only loss came via disqualification after he delivered a low-blow to his opponent—he traveled to New York for a series of matches in 1926. He won 11 of his 12 matchups, drawing once.
Baldock’s impressive victory in a November 1926 fight against American Tommy Lorenzo was documented by the New York Times’ James P. Dawson.
“Only Lorenzo’s gameness and recuperative powers enabled the east side lad to survive the six rounds,” the Times wrote. “He was floored twice during the bout, once in the second round and again in the fourth session, under terrific rights to the jaw, and several times was sent staggering around under Baldock’s pless fire.”
Quick fact: Teddy Baldock and Tommy Lorenzo
At the time of the 1926 fight, Baldock, who was just over 5-foot-6, weighed 122 pounds, placing him in the featherweight division, per the New York Times.
Upon returning home, Baldock ascended to the top of the boxing world.
In 1927, at just 19, he defeated American Archie Bell at London’s Royal Albert Hall—a 15-round fight, won via unanimous decision—to become the world bantamweight champion. “When he fought at the Albert Hall, they said 12 buses left the East End full of people,” Sax tells the London Times. “It was sold out.”
Baldock was the only British boxer to win a world title in the 1920s. Over 81 career fights spanning 647 rounds, he finished with 73 wins (37 by knockout), five losses (one by knockout) and three draws. His career ended in 1931, a decade after his debut. That same year, his wedding drew such large crowds of onlookers that London traffic was at a standstill, ESPN’s James Dielhenn writes.
Injuries forced Baldock to retire at just 24. He subsequently fell into poverty, lost more money during the London bombings in World War II and died in relative anonymity in 1971. Sax, who was 2 when Baldock died, has helped revive his grandfather’s memory in the public’s consciousness. The statue was a major part of this effort.
“We understand this is a very distressing time for members of our community to have a monument of a local hero treated this way,” detective superintendent Oliver Richter says in a statement, per BBC News. “I want to assure the public that our officers are working at pace to identify those responsible and will continue to follow every available line of inquiry.”

articles.content:
Testing Menstrual Blood for HPV Might Provide a Less Invasive Way to Screen for Cervical Cancer, a New Study Suggests
While the method shows promise, some experts say that other self-collection devices are more readily available
Signs of cervical cancer-causing human papillomavirus (HPV) could be found in menstrual blood, offering a potentially less invasive and more accessible alternative to the often-dreaded pelvic exam. Samples collected via cotton strips placed atop sanitary pads provided similar test results as those gathered the standard way, according to a Chinese study published February 4 in the journal BMJ.
High-risk versions of HPV can cause cells in the cervix to change in abnormal ways and lead to nearly all cases of cervical cancer, which is why regular screening is critical. While testing positive for the pathogen does not mean a person has cancer, they are at an increased risk of developing it. In the United States, people ages 25 to 65 with uteruses are generally recommended to get screened every three to five years. But about one in four individuals is not up to date.
“Cervical screening can be difficult for some women for many reasons, like if they have had a bad previous experience, they are menopausal, they have a physical or learning disability, cultural barriers or are a survivor of sexual violence,” says Athena Lamnisos, the chief executive of the gynecological cancers charity Eve Appeal, to Philippa Roxby at the BBC.
Traditionally, a physician uses a medical device called a speculum to slightly open the vagina and then swabs the cervix to collect a sample for laboratory testing.
Did you know? At-home sample collection
In January, the United States issued new guidance recommending at-home collection of samples via a tampon-like device for HPV testing. Private insurance companies in the country must start paying for the costs associated with the tests by January 1, 2027.
The study involved 3,068 women ages 20 to 54 in China’s Hubei province, who were recruited between September 2021 and January 2025. They lived in both rural and urban communities and represented a range of educational backgrounds. Each participant provided one specimen collected by the cotton strip during menstruation and another collected by a clinician for comparison.
Analyses revealed that laboratory testing of menstrual blood correctly identified individuals who were HPV-positive, verified by the presence of abnormal cervical cells, about 94.7 percent of the time. That’s similar to the results from the physician-collected samples, which were accurately identified as positive roughly 92.1 percent of the time.
Additionally, the menstrual blood method led to correct identification of those who were negative for HPV about 89.1 percent of the time, while the standard sample collection technique brought about correct HPV-free results around 90 percent of the time.
“Compared with clinician-collected sampling and invasive self-sampling, non-invasive menstrual blood sampling enhances acceptability and feasibility for large-scale screening,” the study authors write in the paper. “These findings support the integration of menstrual blood-based HPV testing into national cervical cancer screening guidelines.”
Some experts not involved in the study say that while the work proposes a non-invasive alternative to cervical screenings, it still presents barriers and requires more research. “There are important limitations: It includes only women who menstruate and have regular cycles, and it uses a prototype device that is not commercially available,” says Marta del Pino, a gynecologist at Hospital Clínic of Barcelona in Spain, in an expert reaction to the work compiled by the Science Media Centre.
Before the method becomes widely used, researchers will need to conduct more studies in more diverse settings, as well as comparisons to self-sampling methods, she says. “It should be remembered that other non-invasive strategies with solid evidence already exist.”
Xavier Bosch, a cancer researcher at the Catalan Institute of Oncology in Spain, echoes that sentiment in the expert reaction. “My first impression is that this is an area where we already have good tests and that collecting menstrual blood may add more confusion than benefit,” he says. “The work is very pioneering, although it is still in the research phase.”

articles.content:
A White Historian Claimed That Black People ‘Had No History.’ This Trailblazing Scholar Dedicated His Life to Proving Otherwise
Carter G. Woodson, the “father of Black history,” founded the celebration now known as Black History Month in 1926. A prolific writer and activist, he viewed his efforts to educate the public as a “life-and-death struggle”
In February 1926, the eminent Black scholar Carter G. Woodson called on communities across the United States to observe a weeklong celebration of Black history.
Woodson urged members of the public to ask “every church, school, lodge and club” in their locality to host talks and events, and request that libraries stock up on “books setting forth dispassionately what the Negro has thought and felt and attempted and accomplished.” The historian added, “Remember that the preservation of the records of the Negro is not the duty of one man, not the duty of any particular group of men. It is the duty of us all.”
His call to action marked the first Negro History Week, a precursor to today’s Black History Month. The celebration debuted at a time when few scholars viewed Black history as worthy of study. As Samir Meghelli, a curator at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture (NMAAHC), says in an email, Woodson “was often confronted with the bigotry of the historical profession: the near absence of African Americans in history books or, when present, only as never having made meaningful contributions to history.”
Described by many as “the father of Black history,” Woodson strongly disputed white historians’ dismissal of Black experiences. “If a race has no history, if it has no worthwhile tradition, it becomes a negligible factor in the thought of the world, and it stands in danger of being exterminated,” he argued in a 1926 essay.
He “believed that if he didn’t document the chronicles of Black people and people from the African diaspora, if he didn’t write this record, that Black people wouldn’t be acknowledged with their humanity,” says Pero G. Dagbovie, a historian at Michigan State University and the author of multiple books about Woodson. He sought to reach everyday Americans, educating “Black people, Black youth, so they could take pride in themselves,” Dagbovie adds.
Negro History Week’s establishment was just one act in a lifetime dedicated to the celebration of Black history. Woodson also founded an association and an accompanying journal dedicated to the African American experience; wrote dozens of books, journal articles, newspaper columns and book reviews; and mentored a generation of Black historians. As Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie G. Bunch III wrote in a 2015 NMAAHC blog post, “No one has played a greater role in helping all Americans know the Black past than Carter G. Woodson.”
Woodson’s early life and education
When Woodson was a child growing up in the Jim Crow South, he rarely attended school. Born to formerly enslaved sharecroppers in Virginia in 1875, Woodson spent much of his youth helping out on the family farm, making it to the classroom only on days when the weather was too poor for him to work outside.
Despite his lack of formal schooling, the young Woodson exhibited a passion for learning. “His mother was among the minority of enslaved who were literate,” says Meghelli, “and he considered his father—although illiterate and without formal education—a powerful example of what was possible when facing seemingly insurmountable challenges with purpose and determination.” (Woodson’s father, James Henry Woodson, escaped from slavery during the Civil War, joining up with the Union Army and leading his fellow soldiers to nearby Confederate supply depots. After the conflict ended, he worked as a sharecropper, eventually making enough money to purchase a 20-acre farm.)
While working as a coal miner in West Virginia in the early 1890s, Woodson befriended a Black Civil War veteran who was unable to read or write. Determined to stay informed about current events, the man asked Woodson to read the latest newspapers and books out loud to him and his friends. “In this circle, the history of the [Black] race was discussed frequently, and my interest in penetrating the past of my people was deepened and intensified,” Woodson later recalled.
After enrolling in high school at age 20, Woodson graduated in under two years. He went on to obtain a bachelor’s degree from Berea College before teaching briefly in the Philippines, which had recently been annexed as a U.S. colony. Returning home, Woodson received a second bachelor’s degree and a master’s degree from the University of Chicago before enrolling in a history PhD program at Harvard University in 1908.
Woodson “learned to really respect the power of education by being denied it,” says Dagbovie. “He grew up poor, and he saw education as being a window for mobility.” John T. Fowler II, a park ranger at the Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site in Washington, D.C., adds: “Even though he had to go and work and help his family, he never lost that thirst, that zeal for learning. When he got the opportunity to go to school, he took advantage of it, and, essentially, the rest is history.”
At Harvard, Woodson trained under white historians who expressed racist views toward Black Americans. According to an account by one of Woodson’s protégés, the father of Black history traced his life’s mission in part to a conversation with the historian Edward Channing, who told his students that “the Negro had no history.” Woodson disputed this claim, arguing that “no people lacked a history.” Channing tasked Woodson with proving him wrong—a challenge that the younger historian readily accepted.
Woodson’s efforts to preserve Black history
Woodson graduated from Harvard in 1912, becoming the second Black American to receive a PhD from the university, after the celebrated scholar W.E.B. Du Bois in 1895. He was also the only person of enslaved parentage to earn a PhD in history from an American higher education institution.
As Woodson entered the world of academia, he repeatedly found himself barred from white-dominated spaces, including the annual meeting of the nation’s premier history organization. At the same time, Woodson noticed a distinct lack of scholarly resources dedicated to African American history. In 1915, he set out to redress this imbalance by founding the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History (now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History, or ASALH). Because white journals and academic institutions refused to acknowledge Black history, Woodson decided to create an entirely new space for this vital work.
Woodson’s goals in founding the association were twofold. He wanted to establish Black history as a “scientific, rigorous field of study in the U.S. historical profession and in mainstream higher education,” Dagbovie says. But his intended audience wasn’t limited to academics. Woodson wanted to educate ordinary Black Americans, whom he believed had been indoctrinated to think of themselves as inferior.
“Taught the same economics, history, philosophy, literature and religion which have established the present code of morals, the Negro’s mind has been brought under the control of his oppressor,” Woodson wrote in his landmark 1933 book, The Mis-Education of the Negro. “The problem of holding the Negro down, therefore, is easily solved. When you control a man’s thinking, you do not have to worry about his actions. You do not have to tell him not to stand here or go yonder. He will find his ‘proper place’ and will stay in it.”
Writing in 1940, Woodson declared that “the past of the Negro race has been so obscured and belittled by propagandists that little is known of its creditable record.” Through the association and its assorted publications, including the Journal of Negro History and the Negro History Bulletin, he sought “to collect the records of the Negro and treat them scientifically”—a mandate he fulfilled by publishing original scholarship on Black history, assorted documents testifying to the experiences of the formerly enslaved and textbookish overviews aimed at a more general Black audience.
Woodson believed that the publicization of Black history would benefit white Americans, too. As Dagbovie explains, the historian hoped that “if white people knew about Black people’s accomplishments going back to the shores of Africa, they would recognize their humanity … and not discriminate against them.”
Woodson in Washington, D.C.
In 1918, Woodson moved to the nation’s capital, where he taught at a local high school before accepting a position as the dean of liberal arts at the historically Black Howard University. Four years after his arrival in Washington, Woodson retired from teaching to dedicate his time to the association. He purchased a three-story rowhouse in Washington’s Shaw neighborhood, selecting the location based on its “proximity to other well-known Black institutions: Black schools, Black churches, Black businesses,” says Fowler.
The house served as the headquarters of the Associated Publishers, a company founded by Woodson in 1921 to publish the work of Black writers. It also acted as the base of operations for Woodson’s association and its publications. The historian lived on the building’s third floor and used the second floor as an office and library. In the basement, he stored a trove of documents related to Black history.
Now a National Park Service historic site, the Carter G. Woodson Home “served as a training ground for other up-and-coming historians and scholars,” Fowler says. “It served as a library, a warehouse of books. It served as a repository of important documents in not just Black history, but the history of Black people or people of African descent. Most importantly, the home served as the birthplace of Black History Month.” (The historic site is closed for renovations but is expected to reopen later this year.)
Woodson was a prominent figure in local Black circles, mingling with and mentoring other scholars, including Black women like Mary McLeod Bethune. When his organization ran low on money—a common occurrence, especially after Woodson stopped receiving funding from white philanthropists in the 1930s—“he relied heavily on … the support of the Black community, regular, everyday people, giving to the association” to keep it operational, Fowler says. “Whatever money he earned, he put back into the association, he put back into the house, he put back into the Black history movement.”
Did you know? Carter G. Woodson and Mary McLeod Bethune
- Black educator and activist Mary McLeod Bethune served as the first female president of the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History between 1936 and 1951.
- Following Woodson’s death in 1950, Bethune—who counted the historian as a close friend and mentor—eulogized him by saying, “He helped me to maintain faith in myself. He gave me renewed confidence in the capacity of my race.”
The first Negro History Week
Woodson announced the first Negro History Week in 1926, timing the celebration to coincide with the February birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass. The event aimed to document Black lives “from American slavery to freedom and to fill the historical gaps deliberately overlooked to miseducate our children,” says ASALH President Karsonya Wise Whitehead in an email.
“Negro History Week was the first major achievement in popularizing Black history and was unique in in that it focused on the Black youth,” writes Dagbovie in The Early Black History Movement, Carter G. Woodson and Lorenzo Johnston Greene. Woodson had “realized that the miseducation of Black people began in their homes, communities and elementary schools, and he targeted these sites aggressively, focusing especially on the schools.”
Although Woodson’s initial proposal of a weeklong celebration was relatively modest in scope, his underlying goal was to “integrate the study of Black history into American culture, particularly in K-12 education,” Dagbovie says.
Woodson believed that “there can be no celebration without education,” Fowler says. Far from limiting lessons on Black history to this single week, Woodson wanted students to gather information throughout the year and use this time to share summaries or snippets of what they’d learned, Fowler explains. “He felt that eventually, there will be no need for a Negro History Week because Black history will be studied along with other history.”
The public response to Negro History Week exceeded Woodson’s expectations. “Letters poured in from teachers across the country eager to incorporate more Black history into their classrooms,” Meghelli says. “Communities organized Black history lectures, banquets, poetry readings, exhibits and student contests. That enthusiasm only grew over the years and decades.”
By the 1940s, writes biographer Jacqueline Goggin in Carter G. Woodson: A Life in Black History, Negro History Week celebrations had become “increasingly sophisticated and well attended.” The association even sold kits featuring posters, photos and teaching materials for use in classrooms. But not until 1976, when ASALH urged President Gerald R. Ford to issue a proclamation encouraging Americans to commemorate Black History Month, was the celebration officially extended from a week to a full month. Congress formalized this recognition a decade later, passing a law that designated February as “National Black (Afro American) History Month.”
Dagbovie says that the Negro History Week events held during Woodson’s lifetime were “probably more effective than the Black History Months” of today. Back then, he adds, students were actively “involved in doing the learning themselves, rather than just being shown something or asked to watch a special documentary. Even the marketing of Black History Month now, it’s become very commercialized in many ways.”
Woodson’s legacy
When Woodson died in 1950, at age 74, Du Bois praised his establishment of Negro History Week as a “crowning achievement.” An erstwhile colleague of Woodson’s, Du Bois wrote, “I know of no one man who in a lifetime has, unaided, built up such a national celebration.”
Du Bois’ obituary wasn’t wholly positive. Criticizing Woodson as “a cramped soul” who lacked geniality and humor, Du Bois wrote that “in his death, he does not leave many very warm friends; there were few tears shed at his grave. But on the other hand, among American Negroes, and among those whites who knew about his work, and among those who in after years must learn about it, there will be vast respect and thankfulness for the life of this man.”
At least one of Woodson’s friends objected to Du Bois’ characterization. Still, Dagbovie acknowledges that Woodson could be a difficult friend and colleague. He was single-mindedly focused on the promotion of Black history, which “became his life’s work, almost an obsession,” Fowler says. “He did not have a personal life in the sense of kids, family.”
Overall, Dagbovie summarizes Woodson’s legacy as “tangible,” adding, “He left behind institutions that still exist today and thrive.” The association and its journal, for example, continue to operate under slightly different branding. But Negro History Week and its successor, Black History Month, are perhaps the most visible, enduring reminders of Woodson’s lifework.
“Black History Month continues to serve us well,” wrote Smithsonian Secretary Bunch in the 2015 blog post, “in part because Woodson’s creation is as much about today as it is about the past. Experiencing Black History Month every year reminds us that history is not dead or distant from our lives. … It helps us to remember there is no more powerful force than a people steeped in their history. And there is no higher cause than honoring our struggle and ancestors by remembering.”
Learn about Woodson’s legacy by visiting the Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site in Washington, D.C. when it reopens later this year. You can also find out more about the “father of Black history” at sites along the U.S. Civil Rights Trail, including the National Museum of African American History and Culture and Berea College in Kentucky.

These Parasitic Beetles Mimic the Smell of Flowers So They Can Trick Bees and Raid Their Nests, New Research Suggests
They might be the first animals known to fake a floral scent
A beetle species’ larvae seem to bamboozle bees by smelling like flowers. This newly discovered deceptive strategy might be the first known example of an animal imitating floral scents, according to a study posted January 15 on the preprint server bioRxiv. It has not been peer-reviewed
The trickery works like this: Larvae of the European black oil beetle (Meloe proscarabaeus) ascend grasses and cluster together, taking on the appearance of orange flowers, and produce floral-smelling compounds. When a fooled bee approaches them, the larvae latch onto the pollinator and ride back to its nest—where they feast on bee eggs.
“It’s a beautiful study,” says Consuelo De Moraes, a chemical ecologist at ETH Zürich who was not involved in the work, to Erik Stokstad at Science. “It’s amazing to me how sophisticated these interactions are.”
Parasitic beetles use a range of tricks to lure bees. For example, one species emits female bee sex pheromones to attract a specific type of male bee, while another species perches atop flowers and waits for pollinators to gather nectar. But European black oil beetle larvae were known to form strange clumps and chow down on a wide variety of hosts, leading the researchers behind the new work to hypothesize that the insects employ a unique strategy.
So, the team collected adult European black oil beetles in Germany in the spring of 2024 and 2025 and kept them in greenhouse tanks until they mated. The females laid thousands of eggs that hatched a few weeks later. Then, the larvae climbed up grass stems, and the researchers gathered the young creatures for chemical analysis.
The work revealed that the larvae emit 17 compounds that are often found in flowers but are rare in insects. These include linalool oxide and lilac aldehyde, which are known to draw in pollinators. “It wasn’t just that [the beetles] were producing one compound and then loosely trying to mimic a flower,” says study co-author Ryan Alam, a synthetic chemist at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Germany, to Richard Kemeny at Science News. “It was like their own personal larval perfume.”
Did you know? Plants play tricks too
Animals are far from the only deceptive organisms. Many plants also trick creatures into doing their bidding. For instance, the black-bulb yam seems to produce plump, fake berries to trick birds into spreading its offspring, according to a recent study.
Then, Alam and his colleagues made their own blends of larvae-emitted scents to see how bees would respond. The four tested bee species preferred synthetic beetle perfume to wheatgrass, which was used as a control.
The compounds also attracted the larvae, the team found, which suggests that the odor might tell the young ones to gather atop plant stems in early spring, before most flowers bloom. This, the authors note in the study, points to an “intriguing evolutionary scenario” where the larvae may have once been drawn to flowers and then evolved to produce a strong scent themselves, cutting out the need for the natural floral signal.
May Berenbaum, an entomologist at the University of Illinois Urbana–Champaign who was not involved in the study, tells Science that researchers probably find chemical forms of deception less often than visual forms because humans see better than they smell. But, she adds, more examples will likely emerge with dedicated efforts.
“It takes really careful observation and intuition to figure out some of these very strange relationships,” Berenbaum says.
